awd_titl_txt: Toward the molecular unpacking of the PaaC domain, a novel Plasmodesmata-association & activation Cassette
awd_abstract_narration:
Many human diseases and developmental defects are associated with malfunction in communication between cells. Similarly, plants also suffer from uncontrolled spread of diseases, inappropriate seasonal or environmental responses, or improper organ development when cell-to-cell communication goes unchecked. This research, building on unique expertise in cell and molecular biology and computational modeling and machine learning, aims to unravel how important protein regulators are targeted to the channels that connect neighboring cells and fine tune cell communications in plants. New concepts and discoveries made by this research will be introduced to both graduate and undergraduate students as integrated new bioinformatics courses as well as laboratory modules. Furthermore, the software developed from this project will be made available free online to the public together with the source code. In addition, the newly produced data, results, and tools will be incorporated into an existing webserver with user-friendly interface to better serve the research and education community. The fundamental knowledge gained by this study has the potential to be utilized in the long run to engineer genetically encoded synthetic proteins to effectively control nutrient distribution, flow, and fitness in agriculturally important crop plants.

Given the fundamental role that plasmodesmata play in the biology of plants as intercellular communication channels, we know so little about the molecular architecture and mechanisms underlying the plasmodesmal association and regulation. Numerous plant viral proteins, both soluble and membrane-attached, have been studied for a few decades in search for some clues about their plasmodesmal targeting signals and mechanisms. However, no universal signal or mechanism was identified. To address this gap in the current knowledge, the research team aims to unveil molecular mechanisms underlying plasmodesmal-targeting/retention using innate plasmodesmal regulators called the Plasmodesmata-located Proteins (PDLPs). These protein families are found to share an evolutionarily conserved feature which is required for their plasmodesmal localization and function; this novel domain is here named the Plasmodesmata-association & activation Cassette (PaaC). The outcomes of in-depth investigations of the PaaC domain, will provide unprecedented mechanistic insights into how plasmodesmata-associated integral membrane proteins are targeted and anchored at plasmodesmata, and how they may self-assemble to form functional protein complexes. To achieve these goals, the research team will take an integrative computational approach utilizing newly developed machine learning tools and techniques in combination with the state-of-the-art bioimaging techniques. It is anticipated that computational extraction and identification of complex features underlying the PaaC and PaaC-like signals will also serve as a valuable means to identify previously unrecognized plasmodesmal proteins that are encoded by various plant genomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Plant cells communicate through specialized channels called plasmodesmata (PD) - nanoscale membrane-lined pores that regulate the movement of molecules between cells. While these channels are crucial for plant growth and survival, the molecular mechanisms controlling protein targeting to PD remained a fundamental knowledge gap. Our project addressed this gap by investigating how proteins, particularly PLASMODESMATA-LOCATED PROTEIN 5 (PDLP5), are specifically targeted to and regulate these channels. PDLP5 is a master regulator of molecular movement between cells by modulating plasmodesmal opening and closure. Using an innovative combination of cell and molecular biology with custom-built machine learning algorithms, we uncovered previously unknown targeting mechanisms that control cellular communication in plants.

Intellectual Merit

Our research has significantly advanced the understanding of membrane protein targeting to plasmodesmata through several key discoveries:

  1. We have uncovered the role of transmembrane domain of PDLP5 and its family members in homomeric and heteromeric complex formation in addition to its membrane anchoring function. We have also identified critical amino acid residues that are evolutionarily conserved as well as unique to PDLP5 that are crucial for its PD-regulating activity.
  2. We identified novel, unconventional targeting signals in the extracellular regions of PDLP proteins that are essential for PD localization. Unlike traditional targeting sequences, these signals show positional rather than sequence conservation, representing a new paradigm in protein trafficking. Additionally, we leveraged this discovery to develop new machine learning algorithms, specifically Hidden Markov Models trained with both positive and negative examples, enhancing our ability to predict protein localization patterns across diverse sequences.
  3. Our research revealed that the targeting mechanism extends beyond PDLP family proteins to several receptor kinases, suggesting a broader evolutionary conservation of this cellular trafficking pathway. This discovery opens new avenues for understanding protein targeting in plant systems and has potential to extend to other biological systems.

Broader Impacts

This project has generated several significant societal benefits:

  1. Agricultural Applications: Our discoveries about protein targeting to plasmodesmata provide new tools for potentially controlling plant viral infections and enhancing crop resistance to pathogens, directly contributing to agricultural sustainability.
  2. Educational Integration: The project fostered interdisciplinary training across plant biology and computational sciences, resulting in successful mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who published their work in high-impact journals. Our collaborative approach between experimental and computational biology has created a model for training next-generation scientists, particularly in integrating diverse methodologies.
  3. Technology Development: The new computational tools and algorithms developed during this project are now available to the broader scientific community, enabling advances in protein trafficking research beyond plant biology.
  4. Knowledge Dissemination: Our findings have been widely shared through numerous peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and educational materials for case-study examples, ensuring broad access to our discoveries.

Furthermore, this project lays the groundwork for future research into cellular communication mechanisms, with potential applications in biotechnology and agriculture. Understanding these fundamental biological processes could lead to improved crop yields and enhanced plant resistance to environmental stresses, addressing critical challenges in global food security.
